title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. OIOS audits revealed mismanagement in contracts for inspection services in Iraq. The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced mismanagement in contracts for inspection services in Iraq. An audit found that the contractor did not fully perform its duties and failed to maintain staffing levels as per the contract. The OIOS audit found that the contractor in the United Nations Oil-for-Food program did not adhere to certain contract provisions, failed to maintain required staffing levels, overcharged the UN, engaged in unprofessional conduct, and reported inaccurate figures for goods. The OIOS audit found that the United Nations Office of Iraq Programs failed to maintain required staffing levels, overcharged the UN, engaged in unprofessional conduct, and reported inaccurate figures for goods. The OIOS concluded that the office needed to strengthen its management of contracts and designate a contract manager in Iraq. The United Nations Office of Iraq Programs failed to designate a contract manager in Iraq, leading to uncertainty about the services provided. The United Nations has a policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states. The United States was denied access to OIOS audits of the Oil-for-Food Program. The United Nations policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states, including the United States, has hindered transparency and accountability in programs like the Oil-for-Food Program. The United Nations policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states, including the United States, undermines member states' ability to fulfill their responsibilities in UN programs like the Oil-for-Food Program. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. Congress urges the President to ensure that all OIOS audit reports are promptly shared with UN member states without modification, except to protect privacy rights. The Department of State must report on UN officials' financial disclosure requirements within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The Department of State must report on the adequacy of financial disclosure rules for United Nations officials within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with recommendations for any necessary reforms. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines the terms "oil-for-food program" and "Office of Internal Oversight Services" in relation to United Nations resolutions. The curr_chunk explains the term "Office of Internal Oversight Services" as the UN office responsible for monitoring program implementation and conducting management audits. The Office of Internal Oversight Services oversees program implementation and conducts management audits. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate.
